\begin{dem} Let us first assume that  ${\mathrm{add}}\,(P)$ is a coherent subcategory of ${\mathrm{mod}}\,(\Lambda).$
\

In order to get the decomposition ${\mathrm{End}}_\Lambda (P)=\times_{i=1}^t{\mathrm{End}}_\Lambda(P_i)$ as rings, it is enough to see that ${\mathrm{Hom}}_\Lambda(P_i,P_j)=0,$ for any $i\neq j.$ Indeed, suppose there exists a non zero morphism $f:P_i\rightarrow P_j$ for some $i\neq j.$ Since ${\mathrm{add}}\,(P)$ is coherent, we have that $0\to {\mathrm{Ker}}\,(f)\to P_i\to {\mathrm{Im}}\,(f)\to 0$ and $0\to {\mathrm{Im}}\,(f)\to P_j\to {\mathrm{Coker}}\,(f)\to 0$ are 
exact sequences in ${\mathrm{add}}\,(P),$ and thus both of them split. So, we get the decompositions 
$P_i={\mathrm{Ker}}\,(f)\oplus {\mathrm{Im}}\,(f)$ and $P_j={\mathrm{Im}}\,(f)\oplus {\mathrm{Coker}}\,(f).$ Using now that $P_i$ and $P_j$ 
are indecomposable and the fact that ${\mathrm{Im}}\,(f)\neq 0,$ it follows that $P_i\simeq {\mathrm{Im}}\,(f)=P_j;$ 
contradicting that $P_i\not\simeq P_j.$
\

We prove now that ${\mathrm{End}}_\Lambda (P_i)$ is a division ring. Indeed, let $g:P_i\to P_i$ be a non zero morphism. Since ${\mathrm{add}}\,(P)$ is coherent, we have that $0\to {\mathrm{Ker}}\,(g)\to P_i\to {\mathrm{Im}}\,(g)\to 0$ is 
an exact sequence in ${\mathrm{add}}\,(P),$ and so it splits given us $P_i={\mathrm{Ker}}\,(g)\oplus {\mathrm{Im}}\,(g).$ Since 
$P_i$ is indecomposable and $g\neq 0,$ it follows that $g$ is an isomorphism.

The other implication follows from the item (1) of the former remark.
\end{dem}

\begin{abstract}  We explore some properties of coherent subcategories of the category 
${\mathrm{mod}}\,(\Lambda)$ of finitely generated left $\Lambda$-modules, for some artin algebra $\Lambda.$
In particular we look at coherently finitely generated subcategories  and give a connection with the class of standard modules and standardly  stratified algebras.
\end{abstract}

\section*{Introduction.} 
Coherent categories have been extensively studied in the case of modules over commutative rings \cite{H,K,T}. One important feature of them is their connection with a classification theorem of the thick subcategories of the derived category of perfect complexes over a commutative noetherian ring in terms of the ring spectrum.  It seems to us interesting to look at what happen if the ring is not commutative. This paper goes in this direction, we study some elementary properties of coherent subcategories for the setting of an artin algebra.
\

Let ${\mathcal{A}}$ be an abelian category, a full subcategory ${\mathcal{C}}\subseteq{\mathcal{A}}$ is coherent if ${\mathcal{C}}$ is closed under extensions, kernels and cokernels  of  morphisms in ${\mathcal{C}}.$ Thus, a coherent subcategory is  nothing more than an abelian subcategory which is closed under extensions. In section 2, we give some basic notions and an equivalent description of a coherent subcategory.
\

Let ${\mathcal{X}}$ be a class of objects in ${\mathrm{mod}}\,(\Lambda).$ We denote by ${\mathrm{coh}}\,({\mathcal{X}})$ the smallest coherent subcategory of ${\mathrm{mod}}\,(\Lambda)$ containing ${\mathcal{X}}.$ The main result of section 3 is the following theorem.
\

{\bf Theorem} Let $M$ be an indecomposable $\Lambda$-module. Then, 
${\mathrm{add}}\,(M)={\mathrm{coh}}\,(M)$ if and only if ${\mathrm{Ext}}^1_\Lambda(M,M)=0$ and ${\mathrm{End}}_\Lambda(M)$ is a division ring.
\

In section 3, we also give examples where ${\mathrm{add}}\,(M)\subsetneq {\mathrm{coh}}\,(M),$ but still ${\mathrm{coh}}\,(M)={\mathrm{add}}\,(N)$ for some other $\Lambda$-module $N.$ In section 4, we deal with the set of standard modules and 
standardly stratified algebras. The main result in this section is the following theorem.
\

{\bf Theorem} For the set of standard modules $\Delta,$ we have ${\mathrm{coh}}\,(\Delta)={\mathrm{mod}}\,(\Lambda).$

\noindent Some consequences, of the above result, are also given in section 4.
\

In section 5, we deal with the category ${\mathrm{mod}}\,(P)$ of $\Lambda$-modules having a presentation in 
${\mathrm{add}}\,(P),$ for some projective $\Lambda$-module $P.$ It is well known that ${\mathrm{mod}}\,(P)$ is an abelian category, but in general, is not true (an example is given) that ${\mathrm{mod}}\,(P)$ is an abelian subcategory of ${\mathrm{mod}}\,(\Lambda).$ The main result of this section is the following theorem.
\

{\bf Theorem} Let ${\mathcal{X}}$ be a coherent subcategory of ${\mathrm{mod}}\,(\Lambda).$ Then, the following statements are equivalent.
\begin{itemize}
\item[(a)] ${\mathcal{X}}={\mathrm{mod}}\,(P)$ for some $P\in{\mathrm{proj}}\,(\Lambda).$
\item[(b)] ${\mathcal{X}}$ has enough projectives and ${\mathrm{proj}}\,({\mathcal{X}})\subseteq {\mathrm{proj}}\,(\Lambda).$
\item[(c)] ${\mathcal{X}}$ is closed under projective covers, that is $\mathbb{P}_0({\mathcal{X}})\subseteq{\mathcal{X}}.$
\end{itemize}
